Award.AwardTitle: SNM: Continuous and Large Scale Nanomanufacturing of Graphene and Carbon Nanotube Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: This project addresses fundamental challenges in key aspects associated with scalable synthesis, patterning, and integration of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and graphene. Novel high-throughput scalable nanomanufacturing (SNM) techniques are being pioneered with the capability of continuous processing of revolutionary carbon-based devices and hybrid systems, promising a transformative leap in the commercialization of carbon nanomaterials. The success of this work may jumpstart bulk production and practical large area applications based on graphene and CNTs. The project also implements a strong outreach and educational plan aimed at promoting science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) education among underrepresented groups. The knowledge and experience gained in these fabrication technologies are being made available to the broader scientific community through conference presentations, journal publications, and the user network of the NSF-supported National Nanofabrication Infrastructure Network (NNIN), where the University of Michigan is one of the NNIN sites.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: The objective of this project is to invent and develop new high-throughput SNM technologies that will bring graphene- and CNT-based nanomaterials and their hybrids to practical large-area applications in electronics, optoelectronics, and mechanics. A multidisciplinary approach has been adopted to address fundamental roadblocks hindering continuous nanomanufacturing of carbon nanomaterials. A fundamental understanding of processing mechanisms enables the design of machines and processes that in turn provides high-throughput manufacturing of nanoscale structures, devices, and systems using carbon-based materials. The project includes building a laboratory-scale machine for continuous chemical vapor deposition (CVD) synthesis of CNTs and graphene on flexible substrates, and the integration of a suite of novel and scalable patterning and modification techniques suitable for large-area carbon nanomaterial films. Together, the SNM technology is being used to build and test CNT- and graphene-based hybrid photovoltaics, metamaterials, and high-surface-area filters. The project also implements a summer research opportunity program, and creates a mobile educational exhibit and associated activities that can help engage underrepresented student at conventions of the national societies such as the National Society of Black Engineers. Students are receiving cutting-edge training in nanotechnology, while gaining valuable experience in understanding what is necessary to commercialize nanomaterials and manufacturing processes via interactions with industrial partners.

Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

Performance_Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our SNM team proposed to invent and develop new high-throughput scalable nanomanufacturing (SNM) technologies that will bring graphene and nanotube (CNT) based materials and their hybrids to practical large area applications in electronics, optoelectronics, and mechanics. Carbon nanotubes can be produced in a variety of ways but each method has tradeoffs. One method called Chemical Vapor Deposition(CVD) uses tiny particles as a seed for the Carbon Nanotube to grow. When nanotubes grow from seed particles that are close together they push on each other and grow in the same direction forming a forest. The forest is made up of very pure nanotubes and has unique uses, Yarns can be drawn from the forest and 3d shapes can be grown as if by extrusion from seed particles in a pattern along with many others. The forest can grow for a long time but then stops suddenly when the number of active seeds falls and nanotubes no longer push on each other. The disadvantage of CVD is that the recipe, including the temperature, gases, contamination, and the exact steps, must be exactly controlled or the forest will not grow efficiently. We grew nanotubes in a typical CVD process but also used a high energy laser pulse to modify the process, when a nanotube is exposed to the laser the bonds in the nanotube can break and the carbon is vaporized. When the laser pulse is added just as nanotubes begin to grow the nanotube forest is destroyed but then regrows for a longer period of time and 50 to 150 times taller. A common industrial method to create nanotubes is to vaporize a solid target made of carbon and metal with a laser pulse; the metal gas condenses into a seed particle that absorbs the carbon gas and grows a nanotube. The method used in this work combines both that laser vaporization method and the CVD method so that nanotubes can be produced in very large volumes but without sacrifices purity, length, and control of the nanotube diameter and thickness. Our method is a new way to manipulate the energy and atmosphere of the seed particle to combine the advantages of two methods, purity and control of CVD with the high volume of laser vaporization. We also developed the technology and gained scientific understanding on the principles of continuous manufacturing of graphene films by CVD, using the concentric tube reactor design reported in 2013 and updated in 2014.  This reactor design uses a thin foil substrate that is wrapped in a helical path around the inner tube and is continuously translated and exposed to the gas atmosphere in the small gap between the concentric tubes. We have also made important contribution on graphene sensor technology. Nearly all existing nanoelectronic sensors are based on charge detection where molecular binding changes the charge density of the sensor and leads to sensing signal. However, intrinsically slow dynamics of interface trapped charges and defect-mediated charge transfer. This bottleneck is overcome by a fundamentally different sensing mechanism based on molecular dipole detection enabled by a novel graphene nanoelectronic heterodyne sensor. Flexible electronic devices have attracted great attention due to their potential ground-breaking revolution in both consumer electronics and biomedical applications. However, the lack of appropriate flexible high speed data transmission system severely limits its portability and functionality. The key to high speed signal communication is the efficient digital modulation schemes. Hence, a monolithic flexible signal modulation scheme is essential to wide range of applications based on flexible electronics. To this end, a fully bendable all-graphene modulator circuit with the capability to encode a carrier signal with both binary and quaternary digital information was successfully demonstrated. To facilitate the device fabrication on large sheet of graphene and other flexible 2D materials, a photo roller lithography prototype was developed to enable continuous patterning over flexible substrate. The exceptional light absorption properties of nanosized CNTs have been utilized to explore photoacoustic applications, especially the ability to generate high amplitude and high-frequency ultrasound. The invention of CNT based phiotoacoustic lens allows focusing of the generated ultrasound to create significant mechanical effect, such as bubble generation and cavitation. High precision invisible scalpels can be envisioned for medical applications, and new THz detection schemes were developed that allow room temperature, high sensitivity, and high speed operation using compact format devices. The program has helped train many graduate and undergraduate students and several have completed their PhD during the program.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 07/29/2016
Modified by: Lingjie J Guo
